Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Social Network Analysis for Solving Minority Health Disparities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is supported under the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Sites program, which is an NSF-wide program although each Directorate administers its own REU Site competition. This program supports active research participation by undergraduate students in an effort to introduce them to scientific research so as to encourage their continued engagement in the nation's scientific research and development enterprise. REU projects involve students in meaningful ways in ongoing research programs or in research projects designed especially for the purpose. The REU program is a major contributor to the NSF's goal of developing a diverse, internationally competitive, and globally-engaged science and engineering workforce. The Social, Behavioral and Economic (SBE) sciences Directorate awarded this REU Site grant to the University of Nebraska ? Lincoln (UNL) in order to stimulate participant interest in social network analysis (SNA) and behavioral health with a focus on minority health disparities. Participants undergo an extensive methodological training in SNA by the project PI while gaining exposure to a range of research topics and potential science research fields. In conjunction with the Minority Health Disparities Initiative (MHDI), they join a collaborative community of transdisciplinary researchers and community health workers from state and local agencies tackling minority health disparities in Nebraska. The expansion of existing REU to Minority Health Disparities is critical for providing students diverse experiences during the summer and expanding the number of students interested in minority health research through innovative methods like social network analysis and culturally sensitive paradigms, such as Community Based Participatory Research (CBPR). Research occurs within 8 participating laboratories that are housed in several departments across two UN campuses. The summer program includes training in professionalism and provide individual career mentoring and cohort activities. Building off of existing recruitment strategies employed by UNL?s Ronald E. McNair Postbaccalaureate Achievement Program, the project recruits junior- and senior-level undergraduates from a wide-range of backgrounds, home institutions, ages, gender, and ethnicity, with emphasis on under-represented minority and female students in the Midwest. Participants are encouraged to pursue careers in behavioral health sciences and have opportunities to present the results of their research to both other REU participants and to a wider audience of health practitioners at the annual Nebraska Minority Health Summit, co-sponsored by the Minority Health Disparities Initiative.

Since the late 1990s, a combined focus on social networks and health has had a significant impact on both health research and social science. SNA has emerged as a key analytical lens for sociologists, pushing relational sociology forward at a rapid pace in the last two decades. It has also emerged as a set of general purpose tools and approaches which cross-cut a range of sciences. Without exaggeration, researchers working on networks choose freely among techniques and measures developed from fields as distant as computer security, virology, primatology, and studies of the world-wide-web. Social science, and social network analysis have much to contribute in such a transdiciplinary realm. SNA is among the oldest and most rigorous approaches to network analysis, and one with a rich empirical base. While physicists model human networks as metaphors of more basic physical material, SNA researchers have traditionally sought to draw their abstractions from the actual interaction of human beings. The potential of this approach to influence public health and related fields is already apparent. What is needed now is less borrowing, and more researchers trained across newly interwoven fields. In this program, REU participants learn basic approaches to network SNA and then employ these skills in a range of sponsoring NIH- and NSF-funded research projects at UNL and the University of Nebraska Medical Center (UNMC) that focus on minority health and health disparities. Network training takes place in a 2 week intensive network science practicum, followed by 8 weeks of participation in an MHDI-affiliated research project. These projects are united by a collective focus on fundamental questions related both to minority health and to broadening participation in minority health, and are currently funded by a range of federal and state sources. The project is co-funded by the EPSCoR program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
At the University of Nebraska-Lincoln (UNL), researchers are actively developing the capacity to collaborate using innovative methods to address health disparities and minority health. The University of Nebraska’s Minority Health Disparities Initiative builds ties across communities and campuses by strengthening infrastructure, breaking down traditional academic silos and adopting an interdisciplinary and translational approach that includes science, practice, policy, and training.  Our Minority Health Disparities Research Experiences for Undergraduates (MHD REU) site allowed our interdisciplinary faculty provide a research experience rooted in network analysis. Our recruitment efforts targeted undergraduates from historically under-represented racial, ethnic, and geographical groups who intend to pursue a research career in reducing minority health disparities, and has expanded the number of URM students seeking social science and health careers.

Participants of the MHD REU program learned basic approaches to Network science and Social Network Analysis and then utilized these skills while conducting NIH- and NSF-funded research projects in our lab. Our MHDI REU received more than 750 applications in its first three years—60% of which are from historically URM applicants and 75% from women. Assessment of our REU program reveals that the outlined goals and objectives have been achieved and that we have established a highly successful training program. Our program has provided students of diverse backgrounds with significant research experiences that have influenced and shaped their development as young scholars. Our objective and subsequent outcomes for this grant were four-fold:

  1. Provide a total of 30 undergraduate students with intensive training in minority health disparities and social network analysis.
  2. Provide REU students with an eight-week summer research experience under the supervision of faculty working on minority health disparities.
  3. Provide a series of professional development activities over the 10-week summer program to help participating students prepare for graduate research and diverse career paths in the social and behavioral sciences, medicine, and public health.
  4. Increase in the number of highly competitive URM undergraduates applying to social science graduate programs, medical schools, and public health professional programs.

Outcome 1: Provide a total of 30 undergraduate students with intensive training in minority health disparities and social network analysis. Each summer, UNL Professor of Sociology Kirk Dombrowski (PI) taught a two-week intensive training class on Social Network Analysis. This training provided students with new research abilities and skills that they were then able to use in their laboratory experience during the subsequent eight weeks. The outcome for this objective is an introduction to social network terminology, visualization, and exploration via existing open-access data platforms (Pajek and R).

Outcome 2: Provide REU students with an ten-week summer research experience under the supervision of faculty working on minority health disparities. The ten-week research experience introduced undergraduate students to quantitative and qualitative research in a laboratory while emphasizing alignment with the community-based participatory research (CBPR) framework. For many REU students, this was their first time directly participating in organized scientific research. This exposure complemented the methodological training provided during the SNA seminar and encouraged students to envision their own role in research innovation. The primary outcome was student participation in transdisciplinary research where (working with the PI and co-PIs) they facilitated the introduction of new methods to an existing project.

Outcome 3: Provide a series of professional development activities over the 10-week summer program to help participating students prepare for graduate research and diverse career paths in the social and behavioral sciences, medicine, and public health. Each year, students participated in a case- based workshop and discussion of research ethics; practice taking the GRE; learned how to select a graduate program; how to apply for grants to fund their graduate training (including NSF GRFP); developed a concept paper on their own research interests; and presented a poster about their summer research project in a university wide research fair with more than 100 summer research participants. The students also attended research based workshops aimed at exposing them to a wide variety of research methods including community based participatory research, mixed methods research, and evaluation methodologies.

Outcome 4: Increase the participate of URM undergraduates applying to graduate programs. While small in national terms, the addition of 30 URM undergraduates to the ranks of graduate education in the social sciences was an important goal. A majority of the MHDI REU students have enrolled in a graduate program since their participation; furthermore, conference presentations and publications have been made by the MHDI REU students since their participation. The program has increased in the number of highly competitive URM undergraduates applying to social science graduate programs, medical schools, and public health professional programs.
